displayed_text: Patient: So we’re not going back to C__. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. I got that part of it. Family Member: Is any part of the change in the uh the lymph nodes, would that have anything to do with the testosterone or are you just saying that we’re not hormone sensitive so that probably did exacerbate the situation? Doctor: Well, we’ve been scanning you along the way. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So you know when we were on enzalutamide we saw things getting bigger. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And it looks like, you know, that’s always a concern with us giving the testosterone, the possibility it could make things worse. It sort of looks like it’s just a continuing monitor. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Things are progressing along at a certain pace, and we haven’t really changed the much of that. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Slow sort of speak with either thing that we tried.

Patient: As long as I’m feeling up to it. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. We can fill one of those papers out. Yeah. Patient: Okay. What else did I have? Doctor: If you need to go upstairs, you can. Patient: You can go up and take care of it. Doctor: You’ve got to take care of business. Go ahead. You know we’ll be here a while. (Laughs) Family Member: I may have to go sign an order. Doctor: He wrote down the questions? That’s pretty good. Family Member: Well, yeah. I mean, I am his daughter. (Laughs) Doctor: Does that mean it’s going to execute. I mean. Patient: I’m not as thorough as she is about things. My notes are really basic. Patient: Okay. What are some of the things that I should really be on the lookout for, the fatigue? Doctor: I think really just the tiredness. If you feel like you’re more off balance, you know, let’s say it’s weeks from now, that’s something also that’s pretty subtle that can come up just like that (snaps)

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.strongly agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::strongly agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Family Member: So would you suggest that he goes and see Dr. ____ uh when he’s scheduled or; now tomorrow he’s going to see - Patient: Another urologist. Family Member: A urologist that saw him up in the hospital, which is up in our area. Doctor: Yeah, I know that Dr. ____ reached out to you after you got to the hospital. So you know what he feels he can do versus there; most of what it sounds like is very just bread-and-butter urology. And you know um, we saw ya and we were worried that your kidney function had taken a bump. And it just got worse. And that’s why I want him to check it within a few days. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And within that few days it had already gotten worse and because your kidney function was bad, that makes you have nausea and then you sort of – Patient: Right. Doctor: They come in, which, and you know when they looked at your picture um it really was where this was all started — that’s the problem because you can tell just by them just having to put a catheter in, that uh once your bladder gets empty and kidney functions get better. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh yeah so those are issues we have to talk about whether or not there is any role for radiation even though that’s not going to fix the big problem. It may help you pee better. Patient: Uh hum. Family Member: Um now since the cancer has spread, that the main problem

Patient: Hi, how are you? Doctor: Good. Can I..can I steal that chair? Patient: Sure. Doctor: And that way I can look at you. I can move that one over too. Patient: Can I sit here? Doctor: You can! Patient: Well he put the cameras. Doctor: Oh gee that M___. (laughing) Patient: Oh yeah, that’s right. Doctor: How are you feeling? Happy New Year, by the way. Patient: Thank you. Oh, Hi. How are you?

Family Member: I’ve noticed that when he gets enough rest- Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: He seems to tolerate the next day better. Doctor: Uh huh. Family Member: Even if he’s uncomfortable, he’s not irritable and tired – Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: But the lack of rest contributes to a lot of issues for both of us. Doctor: Um hum. Sure. Yeah. That will help with uh you feeling better during the day, too. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Right. I see what you mean. Okay. So let me have S___ come in – Family Member: Okay. Doctor: -and give you a copy of the consent.

Family Member: He thought it was better for the body. Doctor: Yeah, it’s not as a home run, you know, there’s nothing that tells me we should do it off road to do that at this moment. Patient: Yeah, okay. Doctor: That’s probably the best way to say it. Nothing that says oh, man, this abstract tells me this is like a home run. No, I think it just adds more side effects. Patient: Yeah, okay, good, okay Doctor: Yeah, so, I know prostate cancer is the one cancer we can’t seem to plot. We love combining stuff. Patient: Right. Doctor: We’re all like crazy mad scientists in the back. Go, here’s what I, look, that’s what we like to do but with prostate cancer every time we do that it doesn’t behave. It either does nothing but give you more side effects or it just causes a problem. You know, like if you combine this with Zytiga you get more fractures. That’s no good. Patient: Right, I remember you saying that at one of our visits you were saying that. Doctor: Yeah and so just because theoretically like well, they should kind of work together. Patient: Right, Right. Doctor: It just doesn’t so we learned most of the drugs in prostate cancer it’s not like the other cancers where you do two or three drugs together. You know, we’re kind of like the loner group so it’s one at a time, sequence matters with one. Family Member: So this other doctor is going to explain the side effects he may get from radiation?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: which why I told J___ let’s give it another whirl before you know you get too… Patient: Yeah absolutely. Doctor: …pooped out from the Taxotere. So I got M_____ on it. I’m just trying to look at your ankles over there. Just swelling more or what’s? Patient: No. Doctor: Oh, it’s just your socks. Okay. Patient: Just socks. She was checking I think for swelling. Doctor: Yeah. She’s pretty good. Patient: In fact I think um Doctor: Okay Patient: Dr. S____ put me on um oh what is it? It’s a, it must be a diuretic, but it’s I can tell you… Doctor: Mmm. Oh hydrochlorothiazide or Lasix? Patient: It’s not a Lasix or at least I don’t know (sound of zipper)

Family Member: Okay. And that’s the injection he has? Doctor: No. Family Member: No? Doctor: No. The injection he has right now is uh, the hormone therapy, the Lupron. Family Member: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: That will continue. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But we have to do something different to add on to this uh treatment. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Right now to try and control the growth and growing part of the cancer. Okay? And one way to do that is there standard treatment. So there are medications, pills, hormonal pills, that you could take at home every day, and about once a month, every two or three weeks, I will need to monitor you. So you will need somewhat closer monitoring because of that. Family Member: More visits? Doctor: Yeah. The other option is uh to go on a clinical trial which will give us both these medications, and both of these medicines are IV, but you have to come even more frequently for that. Family Member: So, like every other week or something like that?

Patient: Right. Doctor: And so do we just sort of like stay low or if you get better, if the prostate shrinks and we are able to get the catheter out, then we did the right thing. Or if time goes on and you still have trouble getting that catheter out, uh would radiation help? Is it because the drugs aren’t doing what they need to do to shrink it to allow you to have a reasonable channel to get the pee out? Um and that’s sort of – before when we had chemo and before we had these super hormones, some of us would send you to radiation. And then now we don’t know because you can’t get the radiation and the chemo and the hormone all at the same time. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Because that’s just way too much. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Now, is he going to have a body scan at one point to see what’s happening with the cancer cells? Uh she should have that body scan uh that Dr. ____ said that it’s . Now is it down the road? Is it something that you plan to do or does it matter? Or how would you know that the cancer is shrinking? Patient: That the cancer is shrinking. Doctor: So if his PSA drops. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So if he’s not on a clinical trial, I don’t get new pictures. Family Member: Ah, okay. Okay. Doctor: Because my sense is if you are well and your PSA’s down I assume the cancer is shrinking. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Is that Xtandi a, a injection or a pill or – Doctor: It’s a pill. He takes four pills a day. Family Member: Oh, alright. I get it. Doctor: Gives you fatigue, tiredness. Patient: I had two extra bottles I gave back to Family Member: And then, uh, and then he’s going to take it for awhile. And he’ll come down here and get -- in a month or how--how soon? Doctor: So what’s gonna happen is we’ll put the prescription in – Family Member: Yep. Doctor: They’ll let us know, and then by e-mail, we’re gonna – or in MyChart – we’re gonna know whether or not you can start it. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then if you start it, then after two weeks – Family Member: Ahhhh.

Healthcare Professional 1: Oh. Doctor: G_? Healthcare Professional 1: He had progression on his bone scan and CAT scan. That’s what he might have gone through. Doctor: Oh, could be. But his bones are not progressed. It’s just the, um, lymph nodes. (Pause) Patient: No. Doctor: I’m the one bringin’ it up because I see it on the scan. Oh!! We gotta do something. We gotta do something. But, from a functional day-to-day, it’s not really buggin’ you. If you were peeing poop, it would bug you. You would know it. It would frighten the heck out of everybody, but that’s not what’s happening. So, here’s a chance where we can proactively think about it and not wait until it’s an emergency. Patient: I’m not peeing poop. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: It would come out as poop or what? Doctor: Yep. Patient: And I would know, I would know it? Doctor: Oh, yeah. It would smell like poop! Patient: Oh.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, M___’s lookin’ to see. We have about two trials to consider. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But one of them, I just gotta make sure. The one that I am thinking of, I have to make sure that there is an opening. You know how the drill goes. Family Member: Yes. Yes. Doctor: But the good news is the scans were just done. It really does not show. Patient: That’s good. Doctor: That it’s gone “kablooee.” Yeah. Patient: The only thing that was concerning me Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Was that occasionally I have some hip pain, but I don’t. Ya know.. Doctor: Mm-hmm. Patient: You know, I’m not sure that that’s not.. uh, oh

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But your insurance today is not playing nice and it’s not letting us treat you today. Family Member: What? Doctor: Uh huh. Yes. K__’s yelling at somebody on the phone. United Health Care is not being very nice to you right now. And you know we put this in I don’t know how long ago right since the last time I’d seen you. They have hemmed and hawed and hemmed and hawed and given all sorts of problems. Patient: What do I need to do? Doctor: I don’t know. Patient: Can I do anything. I mean… Doctor: Yeah I mean I think if we don’t get an answer today we’re gonna have to shoot somebody there. Doctor: That’s on video too. Yeah. Patient: We got this. Doctor: Yeah… Patient: Is there anything… Doctor: Well the good news is – no – I mean the good news is you know whether you get it today or next week, it doesn’t matter. You’ll still do well.

Family Member: Because I buy sugar free cookies every now and then. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. Family Member: He’s not doing bad because I’ve seen him worse. Doctor: This is much better than Family Member: Yeah Doctor: what we started off in. He was, you were mighty sick when we started so. Family Member: Yeah Doctor: Between your kidney’s failing and hurting and the infections, I mean there were multiple other things that were being thrown at us. Family Member: Yeah and he’s showing an improvement in between – in most all areas… Doctor: The treatment is working and things are looking up. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay.

Family Member: And I’m wondering if it was part of - Doctor: No if it’s some of the pressure. Yeah although if it hurts after exertion it may not be nerve related. I wish they would have done and EMG at the same time of your feet. Patient: I know it. I know it. Doctor: Yeah if you had mentioned this - Family Member: Well yeah. Doctor: They would have done both. Family Member: I didn’t think about that. Patient: Anyway… Doctor: You’re gonna need that. When is the neurosurgeon appointment? Patient: Next week. Doctor: Okay. Alright because I think we are going to have to hold off a lot of decisions then for their input. Patient: If there’s a decision to be made I mean… Doctor: About your treatment, yeah. If it’s surveillance it’s easy because we’re sort of…
